title: Will Syrian government forces retake the city of Aleppo before 1 July 2016?
preds: Now no chance of Aleppo being retaken before the date.
With just hours to go, surely not. http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/hezbollah-syrian-govt-clash-over-aleppo-impossible-take-report-1337512772

Very likely that Syrian government forces *will* retake Aleppo soon, perhaps in the next month. The current offensive seems to been redirected towards cutting off the rebels' supply lines, rather than taking the remaining rebel positions in the city itself. It seems now that the city will only fall to government forces if the Rebels decide to pull out. Given that they are facing being surrounded, it could make sense for them to do this (hence a prediction above 0%); however, in similar situations elsewhere (Damascus for instance) rebel forces have preferred to fight it out, or to rely on negotiated settlements rather than make a tactical withdrawal. The chances of Syrian troops retaking Aleppo by tomorrow seem very slim indeed, therefore.

Almost at the end date here. Probably won't happen. Government is making gains to retake the city, but may not do so in the next day or two.

This is a rapidly unfolding situation. In the past 24 hours, Syrian government troops have made major gains to the north of the city. Some reports state that Syrian army units have penetrated, and are holding parts of the city centre. There are also reports suggesting that government troops wish to take the city completely by the end of Ramadan in order to maximise the propaganda value of their victory. Certainly, continuing air strikes and heavy shelling suggest that a significant offensive is under way.
The opposition still controls a good portion of the city

"The monitor said factions fighting under the banner of the Free Syrian Army (FSA), some supplied with arms by Turkey and other foreign backers, captured the town of al-Rai after fierce battles with the militants (Al-Khalidi, 2016).
Al-Monitor recorded regime airstrikes against 17 rebel-held villages and towns in Aleppo’s northern countryside from May 31 to June 11. In contrast, IS-controlled towns in Aleppo’s northern countryside were spared any regime air raids (Al-Monitor, 2016).
General consensus. Proximity to end date

I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

Based on news sources from Feb to present there seems to exists no chance the Government forces of Syria will retake full or partial control of Aleppo within this time line. The numerous fractions of Syrian rebel fighters i.e.  Al-Nusra, Free Syrian Army (FSA), and a coalition of other minor groups of rebels fighting the Syrian government, have slowed down any chance of the Syrian Democratic Forces retaking Aleppo from ISIS. The rebels, so far have gained no ground in their efforts to remove ISIS forces out of northern Aleppo province. The Syrian Democratic Forces have in fact suffered several setbacks, villages retaken by rebels in their attempt to advance on Aleppo cutting off their supply routes. Therefore, this two-front-war to retake Aleppo is not gaining any real progress.
Short time and no real action in that direction.

I find it entirely all to improbable that the entire city will be retaken, which implies security.  To ensure security one must clear it of traps and that door to door effort will be a longer undertaking then the initial security of the city's parameter.  However, even if retake mean gaining control of the city in terms of majority, I still do not see that happening in the next 2 weeks primarily because of the high potential for a counter surge that is surely to have a slowing down impact for the retaking forces; even if the counter surge is a momentary show and if the slowing down impact is primarily a conceptual (re)assessment

Regaining control of the city outright would be a major win for the Assad government. It remains relatively secure in the capital Damascus, while the city of Homs -- along with Aleppo one of the cradles of the original 2011 uprising -- was regained from rebel forces in May 2014. Should they be able to take Aleppo, the city of Deraa remains the only truly significant population center in relatively moderate rebel hands.

Recent news suggests IS is withdrawing troops from the front lines around Aleppo because of counter offensives in other parts of the country. IS advances also have caused the US to drop more arms to Syrian rebels, increasing the capacity to break IS strong holds in the area. I don't think IS is capable of fighting so many fronts at once - insurgents are pretty bad at doing that - so I give this one a pretty low probability.

Aleppo has been fought over for several years, 1 July is in 45 days. It is variously reported that the Syrian government is resisting committing troops to the Aleppo fight and asking Iran (and Hezbollah) and Russia to take Aleppo. With the recent loss of the Hezbollah commander in unclear circumstances and reported reinforcements for the rebels by people backed by the gulf states, taking Aleppo does not appear to be easy. The attempt to have a cease fire backed by the US and Russia, (regardless that it excluded groups active in Aleppo)  may indicate a recognition that a bloodbath taking Aleppo will not look good for either the losers or victors, may be giving the Russians to pause for thought.

Not within the time frame of the question. If the Syrian Army and allies manage to isolate opposition forces, I don't think they will waste manpower on a dramatic offensive to wipe the opposition out. I think they are more likely to use a seige strategy, which takes a long time.

Syria's military forces are estimated to be half what they were 5-6 years ago. Iran and Russia are playing an increasing role in planning battles and the war overall on behalf of Syria. This means Iran has an informed idea of what's going on on the ground. A major general in Iran's Revolutionary Guard said this when asked about the "liberation of Aleppo": "Asked about the time for liberation of Aleppo in his estimation, the senior official said it will not be an easy job since the northern Syrian city is connected to the Turkish territory from two sides, making it easy for the terrorists controlling the city to receive arms and support.
They might say they did and be there in numbers but fighting will continue. Also, define 'city' because as it stands (err doesn't stand) it already looks like piles of concrete.

As we get closer to the end of June, it becomes more and more unlikely that Aleppo will be retaken. The situation in the city has not changed drastically in the last two weeks, with the large exception of the ceasefire that was negotiated. This would help stall any government forces taking back the city.
adjusting for passing of time, in the last 15 days almost nothing changed (see http://syria.liveuamap.com/ (and especially time icon in the upper right corner ))
Down to a 1% probability from my already well below consensus 3%.
Dropping this to "only remotely possible" territory.

With Russian help, Syrian forces had regained so much territory that the opposition had very few chips to play with at the bargaining table in Geneva. Turkish demand for a no-fly-zone along the stretch north of Aleppo and the Turkish border has not been conceded. The US would not like to dislodge Kurdish influence in that region. A divided Aleppo gives the Syrian opposition at least a toehold.
What I suspect is being sought is a ceasefire along an imaginary line which will then divide Aleppo. The Syrian-Russian combine would like to impose on Aleppo a fait accompli favourable to them. Syria, I am afraid, will probably limp along a path of non-resolution until a new administration in Washington begins to take stock of the situation after November 7.

With a notional ceasefire in the city and the regime losing nearby territory, this will probably not happen before 1 July.

Map Update: Both sides seem to be pursuing the same strategy of attempting to isolate the other. The Syrian army seems determined to break the rebel salient into three separate pockets, whereas the Al Nusra rebels seem intent on isolating the downtown civilian area, and in so doing opening an escape route for their forward fighters (the Al Nusra fighters in southeastern Aleppo are soon to be trapped). The Syrian approach seems to be taking a longer-term perspective, while the rebel approach is more short-term. The pro-Assad civilians in western Aleppo will be bearing the brunt of both strategies. Should the rebels break through, they might use that opportunity to skedaddle out of Aleppo altogether, which could happen quickly. So, in a weird way, any Al Nusra rebel "victory" in near-term local battles might result in Aleppo falling to the government sooner.
https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/battle-aleppo-reaches-uneasy-stalemate-map-update/

Point 1: The international pressure for al-Assad to quit bombing civilians will ramp up very soon. A hospital was recently bombed. Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his allies in Moscow and Tehran have set the stage for an imminent offensive to complete the encirclement of Aleppo City following the near-total breakdown of Geneva peace talks and an associated ceasefire on April 19. Regime warplanes have resumed a campaign of aerial bombardment against opposition-held districts of Aleppo City. Meanwhile, pro-regime forces and their local partners have intensified their efforts to secure favorable terrain in advance of future operations in Aleppo Province. The current confluence of strategic intent, political opportunity, and tactical maneuvers indicate that the regime and its allies will act within the coming weeks to encircle and besiege Aleppo City.  Aleppo City-Syria’s largest urban center and commercial capital – constitutes the primary nexus of opposition strength in northern Syria. If successful, pro-regime forces could deliver a decisive blow to the powerful armed groups in Aleppo City that drives the opposition towards radicalization and a merger with Syrian Al-Qaeda affiliate Jabhat al-Nusra.

Most of the action in Syria since the partial encirclement of Aleppo three months ago has been in other places. But now it looks like Aleppo is once again the focus of the regime's efforts. I still don't think the regime will capture the city in the time frame given, but one interesting question is, assuming the regime takes control of the rebel-held areas of Aleppo, what about the Kurdish enclave in the northern part of the city? It's the red area of the map in this article:

In light of the recent increase of hostilities between both government and rebel forces, it begins to seem that a challenge for control of Aleppo is growing. Both the airstrikes of rebel held territory on 27/04/16 and the more recent attack by rebels on a government held mosque (29/04/16) have completed ended the ceasefire in Aleppo. Even now (29/04/16) there is a 24-hour ceasefire in many different parts of Syria, including Damascus, but not in Aleppo.

Russia has left active participation in the area. Assad will hold his ground. But, it is not easy to gain lands.

"For their part, although Damascus, Moscow, and Iran never viewed the ceasefire as anything more than a temporary measure, the early resumption of fighting around Aleppo is not necessarily good news for the Syrian army. Regime forces had needed a break in the west so that they could focus on important goals in the south and east, such as reopening the road to Deir al-Zour, relieving the loyalist enclave that has been surrounded since year one, and buffering Homs and Damascus from IS raids. The recent victory over IS forces in Palmyra was the first step in that plan, but Deir al-Zour remains the principal goal because it is the key to regaining control of the Euphrates Valley and cutting Raqqa off from the Islamic State's holdings in Iraq. The fact that Assad's best general -- Suhail al-Hassan, nicknamed "the Tiger" -- is on the Deir al-Zour front reflects the town's importance to the regime's broader military strategy."
http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/the-latest-aleppo-battle-may-give-the-islamic-state-another-reprieve

1st July now only 2 months away, but the cease fire in Syria is de facto over. Problem remains that Alepo is a big city that will be difficult to totally retake. More likely it will be surrounded and besieged. The Russians would probably prefer to drive the population toward Turkey to kill two birds with one stone; leave Aleppo with fewer people (particularly civilians) to make it easier to retake; send another wave of asylum seekers into Turkey and toward Europe (to hope to destabilize Turkey and the EU). To do this a corridor towards Turkey is needed, possibly the Kurds could facilitate this.

One of the things I try to mentally adjust for when forecasting is something I call "News Distortion".    There's some sort of principle in physics that says that just by watching something, you change what occurs; "News Distortion", in my mind, is sort of the forecasting parallel.

As of April 22, moving forward, the status of Aleppo relative to military operations and strategy are:  Russia reportedly deploying artillery near Aleppo City. Russia has reportedly raised concerns after redeploying artillery units and personnel to the vicinity of Aleppo City, according to senior U.S. officials. The artillery units had previously been deployed in support of regime operations to seize the IS-held city of Palmyra in Homs Province. The return of these units to Aleppo Province suggests that the regime and its allies may soon intend to encircle or seize Aleppo City.

After a brief respite, bombs are falling heavily on Aleppo, forcing people there to think again about whether it is time to get out of a city at the epicenter of the Syrian war.

Looking at this map, and assuming it's accurate, the regime seems to be expanding its hold on territory leading to the city. A few months ago, there was only a single, extremely vulnerable highway leading from the regime heartland to Aleppo. That area (southeast of the city) is considerably larger now, and has much more depth. Given the time frame of the question, I think the capture of the city by the regime is unlikely. But it may happen later this year.
Am reducing my already significantly below consensus of 10% to an 8% forecast chance. This is over a 50% differential to the 17% consensus GJ forecast.
down again. Seems to have quietened down on this front.
Rebels are heavily entrenched in Aleppo and will be very hard to remove. Homs took 1.5 years to take. On that basis the probability of Aleppo falling in the next 2 months is around 10%.

Once engaged in conflict, it remains in a protracted state until military victory is achieved.   This implies that we will not see any change in the direction of coercive or defensive force but most likely in its intensity.  However, is should be stated that the length of protraction among conflict participants is uncertain, therefore still estimable as a probability.    What indicators, direction and change in the mode of conflict will increase the likelihood of retaking Aleppo by the Syrian government?  Will the coercive capacity of its cohorts (Russia, Hezbollah, and so on) provide increased probability of success.  Most likely.  Increasing the intensity of military power, always lead to success against weaker military forces.   The protraction of the horizon remains the fundamental question regarding the outcome for this IFP.

NYT, April 15, 'Russian Forces Remain Heavily Involved in Syria, Despite Appearances': http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/16/world/europe/russian-forces-remain-heavily-involved-in-syria-despite-appearances.html?_r=0
Clips from article:
"“The level of Russian involvement in Syria is relatively high, and includes a wide range of assistance to the Syrian government forces,” said Mikhail Barabanov, a senior research fellow at the Center for Analysis of Strategies and Technologies.
He and others suggested that Russia was providing close air support, including attack helicopters on the battlefield; high-precision strikes with missiles like the short-range Iskander; artillery support; special forces backup; intelligence; targeting; electronic warfare and, as seen recently in Palmyra, mine clearance.
Although the bulk of the fighter jets flew home to great fanfare, they were replaced by attack helicopters that are less susceptible to the sandstorms that blow this time of year.
Noting Russian news reports that private security contractors were replacing regular Russian troops in Syria, Aleksandr M. Golts, a veteran Russian military analyst and a visiting researcher at Upsala University in Sweden, speculated that the bulk of the force could become some kind of paramilitary organization not directly linked to the government — much like what Russia used to fight in southeastern Ukraine."

Question is a bit fuzzy as far as what retake would really look like. 
Continued Russian air support could be vital to any operation and this will be maintained despite the "withdrawal" (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35812371) which increases the chances of success. 
Progress towards cutting off supply routes improves the chances of the regime to succeed with siege tactics which is what they are already exploring (http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/02/syria-aleppo-assad-russia/462231/). 
However, Aleppo is a rebel strong hold with several thousand opposition troops. The loss of the city would go a long way towards ending that dimension of the war in Syria (other than the fact that it might allow the government to redirect troops to the western part of the country the direct impact on ISIS will be limited) and as such it will not be given up easily. Allowing government forces to control all major urban centres in Syria legitimizes their role and strengthens their hand internationally as they would then be allied against ISIS with the wider international community. Any battle for complete control of Aleppo will be messy and likely prolonged.

Partial withdrawal of airpower by the Russian government does not imply a complete or permanent withdrawal.   The Russians have indicated that they retain their interest in Syria that favors a victory for Assad.  Aleppo, almost completely isolated from the surrounding rebel and terror forces is a primary strategic target for the Syrians and the Russians, as well as Hezbollah and Iran.  With IS having lost 22% of their territory in the Caliphate, it now is concentrated in eastern Syria and western Iraq.   This however does not imply a absence from other strategic areas it holds.  Since IS is stepped in it's religious doctrine of prophesies of the 'end days' in the region of the Middle East, it holds an imperative (religiously) to maintain control and expansion in this part of the world.   Must like the Crusades and the Ottoman's, it is sincerely committed to the extermination and eradication of religious traditions other than its own.   However one can postulate that as degree of territorial control by IS in Syria/Iraq, we can expect increased spectacular acts of terror (that it envisions against the counter-terror forces in its military campaigns in Syria/Iraq.  Consequently, counter-terror activity in the West should increase its deterrent and proactive activity in anticipation of what is to come.   While the most recent campaigns of political violence in Dec, Jan, & February (2015-2016) might appear as disparate, the IS continues to emphasize in its recruitment and training programs (including the lone wolf activity in western countries as well as eastern states who oppose its advance, ie., South East Asia [Indonesia, Philippines, etc.]) that its focus should continue at the transnational (or international level) while simultaneously holding the current territories.   Without territory to create a state (Caliphate), the IS project will be viewed by its actors as a failed project, thereby increasing the potential for exponential factionalism and spurning of more radicalized actors with greater determination to reach its objectives.

Based on media reports, with Aleppo territories controlled by terror networks, the Syrian regime is close to  isolating the control of Aleppo by Jabhat al Nusra and ISIS (nonstate actors)  with the assistance of Russia and Iran.  It is reported that "[t]he regime and its allies will likely retain their battlefield gains if there is no intervention by the United States, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, or the UAE."  While the military balance has been reset by Russia and Iran's support for the Syrian regime, escalation (despite the current cessation of hostilities which remain fragile) will continue, further improving the strategic military and territorial interests of the Syrian regime and its allied proxies (state actors).  This observation provides a strong indicator of how close the Syrian regime is to containment, isolation and defeat of resistance terror networks (ISIS and Jabhat al Nusra ).  If these types of conditions persist over the next three months (just short of the IFP closing) there is a high likelihood that the outcome for the IFP will be YES.  The erosion of terror networks will also lead to strategic loses (in Aleppo) for them if the continued advances of the IRGC (Iran) and Russian forces on the ground persist.  Since Aleppo is almost (but not completely) isolated militarily by the advances of the Syrian regime (and its allied proxies), we can expect a large degree of confidence that this outcome will occur.  Since the conflict will also remain dynamic and ongoing for some time, despite the current (and short) cessation of hostilities, it is expected that the Syrian regime will continue its assault on Aleppo against Jabhat al Nusra and ISIS thereby shortening the current short term ceasefire.
Russian forces will swing the tide in favor of the sitting government.
